title: Urdaneta City University Strengthens Access to Higher Education for Low-Income Students
content: In line with its mission to provide inclusive and equitable education, Urdaneta City University (UCU) has announced a major initiative to prioritize the admission of students belonging to the bottom 20 percent of household income groups in the country. This strategic effort reinforces the University’s strong commitment to advancing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 1 (No Poverty) by ensuring that financial barriers do not prevent individuals from accessing quality higher education.

Through this initiative, UCU aims to open its doors to a greater number of economically disadvantaged students, enabling them to pursue academic excellence and personal growth despite financial challenges. The University envisions a learning environment where education serves as a powerful catalyst for poverty reduction and social mobility, empowering students to improve their lives and uplift their communities.

title: UCU Sets Graduation and Completion Targets for Students from Low-Income Households
content: Urdaneta City University (UCU) has strengthened its commitment to inclusive and equitable higher education by establishing clear graduation and completion targets for students belonging to the bottom 20 percent of household income groups in the Philippines. This initiative reaffirms the University's dedication to advancing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 1 (No Poverty) by ensuring that economically disadvantaged learners are not only welcomed into the institution but also supported throughout their academic journey.

Understanding that access to education alone is not sufficient, UCU’s program emphasizes student retention, personalized support, and academic success. The initiative aims to address common barriers faced by low-income learners—such as financial difficulties, limited academic resources, and personal circumstances—through targeted interventions. By setting measurable graduation and completion goals, UCU ensures that its support systems, from academic advising to financial assistance, are purposefully designed to help these students achieve educational attainment and long-term empowerment.

title: UCUIANS CARE PROJECT
content: The Center for Student Leadership and Development–Character and Values Formation Unit at Urdaneta City University recently launched the inspiring “UCUIANS CARE PROJECT,” themed “Caring Beyond Borders! Healthy Student, Healthy Mind.” This initiative aligns with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 1 (No Poverty) by cultivating empathy, generosity, and community-mindedness among students, emphasizing the enduring principle that caring is sharing.

The UCUIANS CARE PROJECT aims to deepen awareness of the importance of compassion and giving, fostering a campus environment where students are encouraged to think beyond their personal needs. Through this program, participants gain a meaningful understanding of how acts of generosity serve as catalysts for both individual growth and community well-being. By nurturing kindness and connection, the initiative strengthens bonds within the university, promoting a culture of support, understanding, and mutual respect.

title: Urdaneta City University Supports Low-Income Students to Achieve Academic Success
content: Urdaneta City University (UCU) continues to uphold its commitment to inclusive and equitable education by implementing programs designed to support students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. With a focus on learners belonging to the bottom 20 percent of household income groups in the Philippines, the University ensures that financial limitations do not impede their ability to pursue higher education.

Understanding that access to education is only the first step, UCU has developed a comprehensive framework aimed at helping low-income students successfully achieve academic completion. This support structure includes targeted financial aid, academic mentoring, counseling services, and the provision of essential learning resources. These interventions directly address common challenges faced by students from low-income families—such as limited study materials, transportation expenses, and the need for additional academic guidance—ensuring that they are equipped to thrive academically and personally.

title: UCUian Grantees Receive TDP Financial Assistance: Empowering Students, Advancing SDG 1 – No Poverty
content: In 2024, Urdaneta City University (UCU) reaffirmed its commitment to quality and inclusive education by facilitating the distribution of financial aid to 134 student grantees under the Tulong-Dunong Program (TDP) at the UCU Holding Area. The event was successfully organized by the Center for Student Leadership and Development (CSLD), reflecting the University’s continued efforts to support student welfare and equitable access to higher education.

The Tulong-Dunong Program (TDP), a component of the Tertiary Education Subsidy (TES) under the Unified Student Financial Assistance System for Tertiary Education (UniFAST), provides direct financial assistance to deserving Filipino students enrolled in various higher education institutions. Through this initiative, grantees receive support to cover educational expenses such as tuition, learning materials, and other academic needs—allowing them to focus on their studies and achieve academic success without the burden of financial constraints.

title: Empowering Futures: 25 UCU Caregiving NC II Students Receive TESDA Scholarship Grants to Alleviate Poverty Through Skills and Education
content: In 2024, Urdaneta City University (UCU) once again demonstrated its commitment to sustainable development and social empowerment by partnering with the Technical Education and Skills Development Authority (TESDA) – Region I to conduct the Training Induction Program for Caregiving NC II students under the Tulong Trabaho Scholarship Program. A total of 25 scholars from the university’s caregiving program were awarded scholarship grants designed to enhance their technical skills and improve their access to meaningful employment opportunities.

This initiative reaffirms UCU’s unwavering dedication to advancing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)—particularly SDG 1: No Poverty, which focuses on ending poverty in all its forms everywhere. Through this program, UCU continues to strengthen its mission of providing inclusive, equitable, and quality education that uplifts individuals, families, and communities.

title: Empowering Communities Through Culture and Livelihood: UCU Strengthens Ties with Japan in Promoting SDG 1 – No Poverty
content: In 2024, Urdaneta City University (UCU) once again demonstrated its firm commitment to promoting the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)—particularly SDG 1: No Poverty—through a meaningful international collaboration that combines education, culture, and livelihood development.

As part of its ongoing partnership with a Japanese organization, UCU launched a Community and Cultural Exchange Program that provided both educational support and livelihood training to parents and pupils from local communities. The initiative sought to empower families by addressing immediate needs while fostering long-term self-sufficiency through skill development and cultural understanding.

title: Urdaneta City University Policy on Participation and Program Implementation to End Poverty in All Its Dimensions
content: Urdaneta City University (UCU) recognizes education as a powerful tool for social transformation and poverty alleviation. In alignment with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)—specifically SDG 1: No Poverty—UCU is committed to actively participating in and implementing programs, research, and policies that address poverty at the local, regional, national, and global levels.

The University believes that eliminating poverty requires inclusive education, livelihood opportunities, and community empowerment. By fostering collaboration among academic units, local government agencies, private institutions, and international partners, UCU strengthens its role as an agent of change in ensuring that no individual or community is left behind.

title: Urdaneta City University Chosen as Beneficiary of DSWD’s Kalahi-CIDSS Cash-for-Work Program

content: Urdaneta City University (UCU) has been selected as one of the beneficiaries of the Department of Social Welfare and Development’s (DSWD) Kalahi-CIDSS Cash-for-Work Program, a community-driven development initiative aimed at reducing poverty and promoting inclusive growth. The program provides short-term employment opportunities for individuals by engaging them in community development projects that improve public services and infrastructure.

The selection of UCU aligns with the university’s mission of promoting social responsibility, civic engagement, and community development. By participating in this initiative, the university community contributes to meaningful and sustainable development while also supporting the socio-economic welfare of vulnerable individuals. The partnership demonstrates a shared commitment between the government and academic institutions to strengthen community resilience and provide livelihood support.

This activity also reflects the core values of UCU in creating a responsive and engaged academic environment where education goes beyond the classroom and fosters a culture of compassion, volunteerism, and nation-building. Through the Cash-for-Work Program, students and community members alike will have the opportunity to take part in developmental tasks that benefit not only the university but the surrounding communities as well.

sections.title: This projects aims to:
items: Provide eligible UCU students and alumni with temporary employment opportunities through the DSWD’s Kalahi-CIDSS Cash-for-Work initiative.
Promote awareness and understanding of the Kalahi-CIDSS program, including its goals, implementation process, and community development focus.
Encourage active participation of students and alumni in community-based development projects that contribute to local empowerment and poverty alleviation.
Strengthen the partnership between UCU and DSWD in implementing social development programs within academic communities.
Instill a sense of civic responsibility and social involvement among beneficiaries by allowing them to contribute meaningfully to nation-building efforts.

sections.title: Contributions to the Sustainable Development Goals
content: The Urdaneta City University’s (UCU) participation in the DSWD Kalahi-CIDSS Cash-for-Work Program significantly advanced multiple United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), demonstrating the university’s dedication to social inclusion, community empowerment, and nation-building. The program notably aligned with SDG 1: No Poverty by providing temporary livelihood opportunities to qualified students and alumni, directly addressing financial vulnerability and supporting their basic needs. It also reinforced SDG 4: Quality Education by extending learning beyond the classroom and fostering values such as volunteerism, leadership, and civic engagement among graduates. Supporting SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth, the initiative enhanced employability and work readiness by engaging youth and recent graduates in productive work, while SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities was addressed through equal access for all qualified participants regardless of socio-economic background. Furthermore, the program promoted SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities by involving beneficiaries in community projects aimed at improving local infrastructure and services, thereby fostering resilience at the grassroots level. Lastly, the collaboration exemplified SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals by showcasing effective cooperation between government agencies and higher education institutions to achieve sustainable and inclusive development. Through this engagement, UCU not only improved the livelihoods of its students and alumni but also contributed meaningfully to national and global development priorities.

columns.title: General Assessment
content: The Cash-for-Work Orientation Programme was successfully implemented and well-received by participants, offering a clear and engaging learning experience through informative presentations, clarificatory sessions, and the distribution of orientation materials. Attendees actively listened, asked questions, and expressed appreciation for the opportunity to better understand the DSWD Kalahi-CIDSS Cash-for-Work initiative. The sessions were relevant, timely, and aligned with the goals of promoting community participation and youth empowerment via temporary employment support. Participant feedback highlighted the orientation’s effectiveness in clarifying their roles, responsibilities, and benefits, while the presence of DSWD officials and project staff ensured accurate and confident delivery of information and prompt responses to concerns. The event was well-organized, marked by smooth facilitation, active collaboration between the university and agency, and strong logistical coordination, all contributing to its overall success.

columns.title: Recommendations
content: To further enhance the impact of future orientation activities, it is recommended to extend the duration of the Q&A and clarification segments to allow for deeper understanding and more personalized support for participants. Incorporating follow-up activities such as online orientations, regular progress updates, or virtual check-ins can help sustain engagement and ensure continued clarity throughout the program’s implementation. It is also suggested to diversify the pool of speakers and facilitators to include voices from partner agencies, local government units, and former program beneficiaries, offering broader and more relatable perspectives. Lastly, gathering more structured feedback through post-orientation surveys and participant reflections will aid in refining the program’s delivery and aligning future sessions with the evolving needs and expectations of the beneficiaries.
